climbs.name: Chenoo
climbs.fa: Michel Martin and Greg Hughes, February 2020

content.description:
Giant cannibal ice monsters, similar to the Windigo of the Anishinabe and other northern tribes. Chenoos were once human beings who either committed terrible crimes or became possessed by evil spirits, causing their hearts to turn to ice. Pronounced cheh-noo.
Source:  native-languages.org/mikmaq…

Steep, sustained, climbing to some wild formations including large umbrellas near the top. A very enjoyable route.

This route is the first line encountered in the cove as you enter from the north. It can easily be rappelled or you can drop in near the beginning of the cove and walk the beach at low tide.
A rack of screws.

Gitpu is the Eagle in the Mi'kmaq language. Steep climbing on wild features. Several overhanging projections/umbrellas that need to be navigated. A lot of variety in a short route. Very 3D and most enjoyable. 

This it the last route in the main part of the cove moving south. 
A rack of screws.

Gwimu is the Loon in the Mi'kmaq language. This route makes for a great way to get down to the beach (or make your escape) even when it is close to high tide. An easy climb up or down. 

This route is about 150 meters south of Gjiga'qaquj near the south end of the horseshoe cove. 
A couple of screws.

climbs.name: Milita'w
climbs.fa: Michel Martin and Greg Hughes, Feb. 2020

content.description:
Milita'w is the Hummingbird in the Mi'kmaq language. A big umbrella roof makes this more interesting. 

This route is about 100 meters south of Gwimu. The second to last route on the south end of the cove. Faces north. 
A few screws.

climbs.name: Qjiga'qaquj
climbs.fa: Greg Hughes and Michel Martin, Feb. 2020

content.description:
Qjiga'qaquj is the Raven in the Mi'kmaq language. This stunning line can be climbed in one or two pitches. If the tides are approaching or if you just wanted to break up the route, two pitches would make sense. It was done in one long pitch on the fa climbing just left of center until the final moves where a small umbrella was bashed to allow passage directly up the middle. The line on the right will likely have lots of flowing water on it.


400 meters south of Chenoo. The second more prominent route in the area. The top of the route is very close to kilometer 19 of the Cape Chignecto hiking trail.
A rack of screws.

This area's best climbs are located in a horseshoe cove about 1.5 k south of the Little Bald Campground. The cove is mostly north facing so the routes come in early and stay late into the season.
*The names of the routes along this section of coast are all in the Mi'kmaq language. This area has a strong cultural significance to the first nations people who have lived here for thousands of years and the names reflect the legends, stories and names associated with this culture.
